author: ethzed
content:
One relevant thing that came up in our external review is to consider using `aragon2id` for the key derivation function (EIP-2535). This EIP currently specifies two KDFs, `PBKDF2` and `scrypt`. 

- `PBKDF2` computations require very little RAM, making it potentially vulnerable to bruteforce attacks with GPUs.
- `scrypt` is a better alternative, but as mentioned by Carl I think, it takes large amounts of memory (and the data-dependent memory accesses might make it vulnerable to side-channel attacks).

`Argon2` won the 2015 password hashing competition. I know <@!361447803194441738> had planned to commenting on the relevant EIP with this finding, but thought I'd mention it here too ðŸ™‚

author: paulhauner
content:
Something that I've noticed during converstations is ambiguity around the term "wallet":

I tend to use wallet to refer to an EIP-2386 "walletstore", which is just a single JSON file that contains (a) an encrypted seed and (b) a nonce (`nextaccount`) that allow for churning out validators incrementally as per EIP-2334 (Deterministic Account Hierarchy)

I've noticed "wallet" also being used to refer to an ethdo concept of a "wallet", which (I think) is a directory which contains an EIP-2386 walletstore and zero or more EIP-2335 keystores (and an index).

author: paulhauner
content: I think this naming system could be improved. We have a "keystore" which holds "keys" but the "walletstore" doesn't hold "wallets", its the other way around.

author: paulhauner
content: Regardless, I think a VC that wants to sign consensus messages needs not be concerned with either concept of a "wallet". It just has `n` keystores loaded from some arbitrary directory structure.
